author: sky.cactus
content: Transactions pay the same base fee.  They don't have to pay the same inclusion fee.

author: maxvoltage.
content: So... are the wallets going to have 2 entries for people to make for their transactions??  One for overall cost of the transaction and one for the inclusion fee?

author: sky.cactus
content: Advanced wallets might.  My expectation is that the simplest wallets (like CoinBase wallet) will set inclusion fee to something reasonable for you and set fee max to 2-3x what is necessary for next block inclusion and just inform the user of a fee range.

author: sky.cactus
content: Medium advanced wallets will let you set fee cap but will set inclusion fee for you.

author: sky.cactus
content: Highly advanced wallets will let you set both.

author: sky.cactus
content: For most users, the simple solution will work great!

author: maxvoltage.
content: OK, so for those trying to do arbitrage trades and be placed at a specific place in the block, then those will be using the advanced wallets, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Those people almost all use custom scripts, not a UI wallet.

author: mrabino1
content: correct me if i am wrong on this <@!301186049323958275> but another core benefit for this introduction of pricing "certainty" (almost) is not only to help aid the UX for L1 users but also provide a path for rollups to publish to L1 on a routine basis without needing to be in a bidding war (or have a human push the button on what pricing is needed). 1559 should lay the groundwork for L2s to publish reliably.

author: sky.cactus
content: You still need the bidding war, but L2s now can programmatically know how much is a "fair price to pay".

author: sky.cactus
content: So an L2 can use whatever scheme it wants to pay people to publish to L1 and it can know how much is "reasonable".

author: sky.cactus
content: Without it, you need to develop much more complex schemes like escalating gas prices until someone does it or something, which takes time.
